BmimOAc ionic liquid: A highly efficient catalyst for synthesis of 3-aryl-2-oxazolidinones by direct condensation of 2-(arylamino) alcohols with diethyl carbonate Elnazeer H.M. Elageed Binshen Wang Yongya Zhang Shi Wu Guohua Gao ⁎ Shanghai Key Laboratory of Green Chemistry and Chemical Processes, Department of Chemistry, East China Normal University, North Zhongshan Road 3663, Shanghai 200062, China Shanghai Key Laboratory of Green Chemistry and Chemical Processes Department of Chemistry East China Normal University North Zhongshan Road 3663 Shanghai 200062 China ⁎ Corresponding author. Fax: + 86 21 62233323. Graphical abstract An efficient convenient procedure for the synthesis of 3-aryl-2-oxazolidinones from 2-(arylamino) alcohols and diethyl carbonate (DEC) catalyzed by ionic liquids is described. The effects of reaction time, amount of catalyst and temperature were investigated. Excellent yields of products were obtained under the optimized reaction conditions, when using BmimOAc as a catalyst. An intermediate ethyl 2-(phenyl amino) ethyl carbonate was isolated and characterized. 1H NMR spectroscopy and DFT calculations indicated that BmimOAc cooperatively activate the substrates through hydrogen bonding with its anion and cation sites. According to these results, a possible reaction mechanism was discussed. Keywords Ionic liquids Cooperative Catalysis Mechanism Oxazolidinones 1 Introduction 3-Aryl-2-oxazolidinones are important materials in field of medicine and organic synthesis. In recent decades they have attracted much attention due to their bioactivity. They have been used as a new class of antibiotics, HIV-1 protease inhibitors [1–5], fungicides [6] and synthetic reagents [7]. Conventionally, 3-aryl-2-oxazolidinones are mostly synthesized using phosgene or its derivatives with amino alcohols catalyzed by strong organic bases [8,9]. However phosgene and its derivatives are highly toxic reagents and the strong bases limit the use of substrates containing different functional groups. The alternative synthetic approaches via insertion of carbon dioxide molecule into aziridine moiety [10–14], the reaction of amino alcohols with carbon dioxide [15–18], and the reaction of propargylic alcohols, amines with carbon dioxide which are usually catalyzed by copper salts, palladium or tributylphosphine are also reported [19–22]. However, the use of these approaches is required relatively drastic conditions (5.0MPa of CO2 pressure, 110–180°C and prolonged reaction time 9–20h) and the catalysts are highly toxic or expensive. In the course of our studies on the utilization of ionic liquids as catalysts, we reported approaches for the synthesis of 3-aryl-2-oxazolidinones via reaction of cyclic carbonates with aromatic amines, and the straightforward conversion of CO2 using ethylene oxide and aromatic amines in the presence of catalytic amount of ionic liquids [23–26]. Although these approaches are regarded as green, they still suffer from relative long reaction time, high reaction temperature or large amount of catalyst. To overcome these drawbacks, herein, in this paper we wish to report the success in synthesis of 3-aryl-2-oxazolidinones in high yields by effective, convenient and eco-friendly approach via direct condensation of 2-(arylamino) alcohols with ‘greener reagent’ diethyl carbonate (DEC) in the presence of catalytic amount of BmimOAc (Scheme 1 ). 2 Experimental 2.1 General Diethyl carbonate (DEC) was supplied by Sinopharm. 2-(Phenylamino) ethanol was obtained from TCI. All ionic liquids were supplied by center of green chemistry and catalysis, LICP and CAS. The other reagents were commercial reagents of AR grade and used without further purification. The 2-(arylamino) alcohols were synthesized by the reaction of aryl amines with ethylene carbonate (EC) in the presence of BmimBr ionic liquid as catalysts (see supplementary data). GC analysis was performed by using a Shimadzu GC-14B equipped with a capillary column DM-1701(30m×0.32mm×0.25μm) equipped with a flame ionization detector. The NMR spectra were recorded on Bruker Ascend 400 and Bruker DRX500 with tetramethylsilane as the internal standard. The DFT calculations were carried out by using the B3LYP functional with the 6–311g basis set as implemented in Gaussian 09 program package. Vibrational frequency calculations, from which the zero-point energies were derived, have been performed for each optimized structure at the same level to identify the natures of all the stationary points. 2.2 Typical procedure for the synthesis of 3-aryl-2-oxazolidinones In a typical procedure, the reaction of 2-(arylamino) ethanol with DEC was carried out in a 5mL round bottomed flask. 2-(Arylamino) ethanol (2.0mmol), DEC (10mmol, 1.1813g) and BmimOAC (5%, 0.1mmol, 0.0198g) were mixed together and stirred at 130°C for 1h under nitrogen atmosphere. The reaction mixture was analyzed by GC with n-dodecane as the internal standard. The pure products were obtained by chromatography on silica gel and structurally characterized by NMR. 2.2.1 3-Phenyl-2-oxazolidinone (1a) 1H NMR (400MHz, CDCl3, TMS) δ 7.53–7.55 (m, 2H), 7.36–7.39 (m, 2H), 7.14–7.15 (m, 1H), 4.44–4.49 (m, 2H), 4.01–4.07 (m, 2H); 13C NMR (100MHz, CDCl3, TMS) δ 155.4, 138.4, 129.2, 124.2, 118.4, 61.4, 45.3. 2.2.2 Ethyl 2-(phenyl amino) ethyl carbonate (2a) 1H NMR (400MHz, CDCl3, TMS) δ 7.21–7.16(m, 2H), 6.73(t, J =7.31Hz, 1H), 6.62(t, J =8.07Hz, 2H), 4.32(t, J =5.41Hz, 2H), 4.22(m, 2H), 3.97(s, 1H), 3.43(t, J =5.4Hz, 2H), 1.31(t, J =7.1Hz, 3H); 13C NMR (100MHz, CDCl3, TMS) δ 157.5, 134.6, 134.1, 129.9, 128.7, 128.6, 127.0, 126.5, 125.7, 124.6, 122.4, 62.6, 49.1. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Reaction of 2-(phenylamino) ethanol with DEC catalyzed by BmimOAC 1-Butyl-3-methylimidazolium acetate (BmimOAc) as one of the imidazolium-based ionic liquids is commonly known as a reaction media and catalyst [27–30]. It has been used as a catalyst for the reaction of N-heterocycles with dimethyl carbonate [31], and the reaction of cyclic carbonates with indole [32]. According to this basis, a preliminary experiment was conducted to identify the products from the reaction of 2-(phenylamino) ethanol with DEC. Two products were detected in the reaction mixture, isolated by chromatography on silica gel and structurally characterized by NMR. They were confirmed to be 3-phenyl-2-oxazolidinone (1a) and ethyl 2-(phenyl amino) ethyl carbonate (2a) (Scheme 2 ). To optimize the reaction parameters, the effects of reaction time, amount of catalyst and temperature were investigated. 3.1.1 The effect of reaction time The reaction of 2-(phenylamino) ethanol with DEC was carried out in different time range of 20–60min. The effect of reaction time on the conversion of 2-(phenylamino) ethanol and the yields of 2a and 1a are shown in Fig. 1 . From this figure, it can be seen that the reaction goes very fast. The conversion of 2-(phenylamino) ethanol reached to 98% in 30min and 100% in 40min. In the meanwhile, there are two products 2a and 1a were obtained. Weidlich et al. [33] reported similar observation during their studies on transesterification of 2-(phenylamino) ethanol with DMC using C, N-chelated organotin (IV) compounds as catalysts. The yield of 2a increased first and reached the highest yield of 66% at 30min, and then decreased smoothly until it disappeared from the reaction mixture in 1h. Meanwhile the yield of 1a was increased by increasing reaction time till reached 100% at 1h. These results showed that 2a probably the intermediates of 1a. In order to prove this assumption, 2a was used as starting material under the catalytic amount of BmimOAc, and the sole product of 1a was obtained in 130°C in 1h with >99% yield (Scheme 3 ). Additionally similar compounds of 2a were detected in the reaction of 1-phenylethanol with DMC [34]. 3.1.2 The effect of catalyst amount The effect of catalyst amount was shown in Fig. 2 . With the increase of the amount of catalyst from 1 to 5%, the conversion of 2-(phenylamino) ethanol increased and reached to 100% with 3% of BmimOAc. The yield of intermediate 2a increased firstly followed by decreasing till it disappeared from reaction mixture, while the yield of 1a increased dramatically. The highest yield of 1a was obtained when using 4% of BmimOAc then remains steady with increase of the amount catalyst. 3.1.3 The effect of reaction temperature The reaction of 2-(phenylamino) ethanol and DEC was carried out in the temperature range of 90–130°C. The effect of reaction temperature on the conversion of 2-(phenylamino) ethanol and the yields of 2a and 1a were shown in Fig. 3 . It is appears that this reaction is highly sensitive to temperature. The conversion of 2-(phenylamino) ethanol reached 100% at 110°C, followed by staying at this point with increase of reaction temperature. From 90°C to 100°C, the yield of 2a was increased rapidly. Further increase in temperature lead to drop of 2a yield. On the other hand the yield of 1a increased smoothly with increase of temperature from 90°C to 100°C, and then it increased dramatically when the temperature reached 130°C. 3.2 Reaction of various 2-(arylamino) alcohols with DEC catalyzed by BmimOAc To investigate the generalities of this procedure, the reaction of various 2-(arylamino) alcohols with DEC was carried out. The results were listed in Table 1 . Under the identity reaction conditions, the 2-(arylamino) alcohols with either electron-donating substituents (such as alkoxy) or electron-withdrawing substituents (such as halides) could be converted to corresponding products in almost quantitative yields (entries 1–5). Additionally, 2-(naphthalen-1-ylamino) ethanol also gave 3-(naphthalen-1-yl) oxazolidin-2-one (1g) in excellent yield (entry 6). However cyclohexylamino alcohols and benzyl amino alcohols, which were possessing stronger electonegativity, are relatively inactive (entries 7 and 8). 3.3 Reaction of 2-(phenylamino) ethanol with DEC catalyzed by various ionic liquids To investigate the effect of different ionic liquids on the reaction of 2-(phenylamino) ethanol with DEC, a series of ionic liquids have been used as catalysts. The results were shown in Table 2 . BmimOAc gave 1a in a high yield (>99%) (entry 1). BmimCl, BmimBr catalyze the reaction to give both 2a in relatively high yields 70, 68%, and 1a in the yields of 21, 9% (entries 3, 5). BmimBF4 does not show any catalytic activity (entry 7). These results shows that the higher yield of 1a is provided by anions of ionic liquids with stronger hydrogen bond basicity [35], which follows the order of OAc>Cl>Br>BF4. BmmimOAc, BmmimCl, and BmmimBr, which contain a methyl group in the C-2 of imidazolium ring, give lower yields of both 2a and 1a in the reaction than their corresponding Bmim based ionic liquids (entries 2, 4 and 6). It demonstrates that the C-2 proton of imidazolium ring of ionic liquids also plays an important role in catalyzing the reaction. The cooperative activation phenomenon of ionic liquids upon interaction with substrates was well investigated by Chakraborti and co-workers [36–40]. It is clear that in this reaction both the anions and cations of ionic liquids play essential role by cooperatively activation of the hydroxyl proton of 2-(phenylamino) ethanol and the carbonyl group of DEC, similar results were observed by our group in the reaction of aniline with ethylene carbonate [23]. In addition, 1-hydroxyethyl-3-methylimidazolium chloride (HOEmimCl) and 1-hydroxyethyl-2, 3-dimethyl imidazolium chloride (HOEmmimCl) gave only 2a in low yields 14, 6% (entries 9, 10), showing that hydroxyethyl group on imidazolium decreases the catalytic activity. Upon treating the reaction with tetrabutylammonium acetate (TBAA) as catalyst, 2a was only obtained in 2% yield. On the other hand, when the reaction was treated without any catalyst, no conversion is observed (entries 11, 12). 3.4 Reaction mechanism studies To investigate the reaction mechanism, 1HNMR spectroscopy and DFT calculation were used to determine the interaction between ionic liquid and substrates. DEC and 2-(phenylamino) ethanol were used as models. 1HNMR titration based on the addition aliquots DEC and 2-(phenylamino) ethanol to BmimOAc was carried out. Fig. 4 shows the shifting on 1HNMR spectra of C-2 proton of imidazolium upon interaction with DEC. When 1 eq. of DEC was added to BmimOAc, the C-2 proton of imidazolium cation shifted upfield from δ =10.51 to δ =10.43. This might be result from the change of the hydrogen bond donor-acceptor pair. In BmimOAc, the C-2 proton of the imidazolium cation acted as a hydrogen bond donor to interact with the acetate counter ion which, in turn, acted as a hydrogen bond acceptor. After stepwise addition of DEC into BmimOAc, the intramolecular hydrogen bond interaction within acetate and C-2 proton was weakened, and an intermolecular hydrogen bond interaction between imidazolium and DEC emerged. These results implied that the carbonyl group of DEC could be activated by the C-2 proton of imidazolium. It is clear that the C-2 proton of imidazolium ring shifted step by step upon addition of DEC due to its interaction with carbonyl group of DEC. Similar results were reported by us and others [24–25,41]. On the addition of 10 eq. of DEC the spectra of C-2 proton underwent significant shift from δ =10.51 to δ =9.97. This indicated that stronger interaction between C-2 proton of imidazolium and carbonyl group of DEC will occur when using excess amount of DEC. Meanwhile when 10 eq. of 2-(phenylamino) ethanol was added to the mixture of DEC and BmimOAC the dramatically shifting in spectra of C-2 proton from δ =9.97 to δ =8.50 was observed. In competition environment both imidazolium and 2-(phenylamino) ethanol acted as a hydrogen bond donors to interact with acetate anion. Therefore upon addition of 2-(phenylamino) ethanol the acetate anion goes to interact with it, leading to the C-2 proton of imidazolium cation free to interact with carbonyl group of DEC, resulting in extremely upfield shifting to δ =8.50. This demonstrated that 2-(phenylamino) ethanol could be activated by the acetate anion through hydrogen bonding. These NMR studies have illustrated that BmimOAc could cooperatively activate 2-(phenylamino) ethanol and DEC by hydrogen bonding. The interactions between BmimOAc and the substrates were also studied by DFT calculation. The optimized geometrical structures of 2-(phenylamino) ethanol, DEC and the complex of 2-(phenylamino) ethanol, DEC with BmimOAc were simulated at the B3LYP/6-311G level (Fig. 5 ). The length of O(1)H(1) bond in 2-(phenylamino) ethanol was elongated from 0.9717 to 1.0199Å after complexation with BmimOAc, and the hydrogen bond H(1)O(3) was formed with a bond length of 1.5802Å. This demonstrates that 2-(phenylamino) ethanol was activated by hydrogen bonding with acetate anion. The bond length of the C(1)O(2) in DEC was elongated from 1.2342 to 1.2416Å after complexation with BmimOAc, and hydrogen bond H(2)O(2) was formed with a bond length of 2.4029Å. These results indicate that DEC is activated through hydrogen bonding between carbonyl carbon and C-2 proton of imidazolium ring of ionic liquid. The DFT calculations indicated that the cation and anion of BmimOAc cooperatively activated the substrates via formation of hydrogen bonds. According to these results a reaction mechanism was proposed as shown in Scheme 4 . Firstly, the C-2 proton of imidazolium cation activates the carbonyl group of DEC through the formation of hydrogen bond (CO⋯H). The activation of carbonyl group by such kind of interaction was also reported in Diels-Alder and acetylation reaction [42,43]. In the same time the acetate anion activates 2-(phenylamino) ethanol by hydrogen bond at the hydrogen atom of hydroxyl group. Secondly, oxygen atom of hydroxyl group nucleophilic attacks the activated carbonyl group resulting in forming intermediate2a. Thirdly, the 2a molecule is subjected to further interaction with C-2 proton of imidazolium cation which activates the carbonyl group and acetate anion which activates the amine group. Last, the activated 2a species undergoes intramolecular cyclization to form final product 3-phenyl-2-oxazolidinone. And BmimOAc is recycled to complete the reaction circle. 4 Conclusion In summary we have described a simple and environmentally benign procedure for the synthesis of 3-aryl-2-oxazolidinones by the reaction of 2-(arylamino) alcohols with DEC in the presence of ionic liquids. Under mild reaction conditions, BmimOAc can catalyze the generation of various 3-aryl-2-oxazolidinones in excellent yields. The high catalytic activity of BmimOAc is attributed to its strong hydrogen bond basicity anion and hydrogen atom in C-2 of imidazolium ring. DFT calculation and 1H NMR spectroscopy indicated that both anion and cation of ionic liquid cooperatively activated the substrates through hydrogen bonding. Beside, ethyl 2-(phenyl amino) ethyl carbonate is considered as the key intermediate in the reaction. coredata.dc:description: An efficient convenient procedure for the synthesis of 3-aryl-2-oxazolidinones from 2-(arylamino) alcohols and diethyl carbonate (DEC) catalyzed by ionic liquids is described. The effects of reaction time, amount of catalyst and temperature were investigated. Excellent yields of products were obtained under the optimized reaction conditions, when using BmimOAc as a catalyst. An intermediate ethyl 2-(phenyl amino) ethyl carbonate was isolated and characterized. 1H NMR spectroscopy and DFT calculations indicated that BmimOAc cooperatively activate the substrates through hydrogen bonding with its anion and cation sites. According to these results, a possible reaction mechanism was discussed.
